metadata.title: Online dashboard and data analysis approach for assessing COVID-19 case and death data
metadata.abstract: The 2019-2020 global pandemic has been caused by a disease called coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19). This disease has been caused by the Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome coronavirus-2 (SARS-CoV-2). By April 30 2020, the World Health Organization reported 3,096,626 cases and 217,896 deaths, which implies an exponential growth for infection and deaths worldwide. Currently, there are various computer-based approaches that present COVID-19 data through different types of charts, which is very useful to recognise its behavior and trends. Nevertheless, such approaches do not allow for observation of any projection regarding confirmed cases and deaths, which would be useful to understand the trends of COVID-19. In this work, we have designed and developed an online dashboard that presents actual information about COVID-19. Furthermore, based on this information, we have designed a mathematical model in order to make projections about the evolution of cases and deaths worldwide and by country.

llm_problem.title: Predictive Modeling for Dynamic Disease Spread and Impact Projection
llm_problem.problem: The challenge of developing robust, real-time predictive models to project the spread and impact of infectious diseases such as COVID-19 (e.g., case counts, fatalities) at global and regional scales. This requires integrating heterogeneous data sources, accounting for uncertainty, and enabling actionable insights for public health decision-making beyond static descriptive analytics.
llm_problem.impact: Enhances pandemic preparedness and response by enabling data-driven forecasting of disease trajectories, resource allocation, and policy interventions. Applications extend to other infectious diseases (e.g., influenza, dengue) and emerging health threats, as well as cross-domain scenarios like environmental risk modeling or supply chain disruption prediction.
llm_problem.motivation: Static visualizations of disease data (e.g., dashboards) provide limited foresight into future trends, whereas accurate projections empower stakeholders—from policymakers to healthcare providers—to anticipate critical inflection points, mitigate risks, and optimize interventions. Addressing this gap is vital for reducing morbidity, mortality, and socioeconomic disruption during outbreaks.
llm_problem.explanation: The abstract explicitly contrasts descriptive analytics (existing dashboards) with the unmet need for *projections*, framing a clear, domain-agnostic research challenge. The problem is well-scoped (dynamic modeling vs. static reporting), broadly applicable (infectious diseases, other dynamic systems), and grounded in a tangible public health priority. Minor deduction for potential overlap with related fields (e.g., time-series forecasting), but the focus on *actionable projections* for decision-making strengthens clarity.

template.name: Technical Framework for Predictive Modeling of Dynamic Disease Spread and Impact Projection
template.description: A structured template capturing technical implementation details for real-time predictive modeling of infectious disease spread, integrating heterogeneous data sources, uncertainty quantification, and actionable public health insights. Emphasizes methodological rigor, quantitative evaluation, and cross-domain adaptability for computational epidemiology and computational social science applications.

properties.label: Core Model Architecture
properties.description: Named predictive model or hybrid architecture employed (e.g., SEIR variants, agent-based models, neural differential equations, or ensemble methods). Specify if custom or adapted from existing frameworks.

properties.label: Heterogeneous Data Integration Strategy
properties.description: Technical approach for merging disparate data sources (e.g., ETL pipelines, federated learning, knowledge graphs, or probabilistic data fusion). Include handling of temporal misalignment, missingness, and semantic heterogeneity.

properties.label: Primary Datasets
properties.description: Named datasets used as model inputs (e.g., JHU CSSE COVID-19 Data, GISAID, mobility data from SafeGraph, or regional health records). List all critical datasets with versions if applicable.

properties.label: Uncertainty Quantification Method
properties.description: Technical method for estimating and propagating uncertainty (e.g., Bayesian inference, Monte Carlo dropout, probabilistic programming, or interval predictions). Specify if aleatoric vs. epistemic uncertainty is distinguished.

properties.label: Real-Time Processing Framework
properties.description: Named framework or custom stack for streaming data ingestion and model updates (e.g., Apache Spark, Flink, Kafka Streams, or edge computing solutions). Include latency constraints if applicable.

properties.label: Spatiotemporal Resolution
properties.description: Granularity of predictions in space (e.g., country, region, county, grid cell) and time (e.g., daily, weekly, hourly). Specify if adaptive resolution is used.

properties.label: Primary Evaluation Metrics
properties.description: Quantitative metrics used to validate model performance (e.g., RMSE, MAE, R² for case counts; AUC-ROC, F1 for binary outcomes; or custom epidemiological metrics like attack rate error).

properties.label: RMSE (Case Counts, Log Scale)
properties.description: Root Mean Squared Error for predicted vs. observed case counts on a log scale, aggregated over the evaluation period. Report as a single number or range (e.g., 0.8–1.2).

properties.label: Maximum Forecast Horizon
properties.description: Farthest time point (in days) for which the model generates reliable predictions. Specify if horizon is dynamic or fixed.

properties.label: Computational Complexity
properties.description: Time/space complexity of the model (e.g., O(n³) for matrix operations) or empirical runtime for training/inference on specified hardware (e.g., '12 hours on 8x A100 GPUs for global 30-day forecast').

properties.label: Intervention Modeling Approach
properties.description: Technical method for incorporating non-pharmaceutical interventions (NPIs) or vaccines (e.g., time-varying parameters, counterfactual simulations, or reinforcement learning for policy optimization).

properties.label: Benchmark Datasets for Validation
properties.description: Named datasets used for comparative evaluation (e.g., COVID-19 Forecast Hub, FluSight, or synthetic benchmarks). Include version or time range if applicable.

properties.label: Model Calibration Method
properties.description: Technique for fitting model parameters to data (e.g., MCMC, variational inference, or gradient-based optimization). Specify if automated or manual tuning is used.

properties.label: Primary Data Collection Period
properties.description: Time range (start–end dates) for the primary dataset used in model training/evaluation. Use ISO 8601 format (YYYY-MM-DD).

properties.label: Source Code Repository
properties.description: Publicly accessible URL to the implementation code (e.g., GitHub, GitLab, or institutional repository). Include specific commit hash if applicable.

properties.label: Hardware Requirements
properties.description: Specifications for minimal/optimal hardware to run the model (e.g., '4x NVIDIA V100 GPUs, 128GB RAM' or 'CPU-only with 16GB RAM for regional models').

properties.label: External Validity Testing
properties.description: Description of methods used to test generalizability (e.g., cross-regional validation, temporal holdout, or synthetic data augmentation). Specify if transfer learning is employed.

properties.label: Ethical AI and Bias Mitigation
properties.description: Technical measures to address bias, fairness, or ethical risks (e.g., demographic stratification of error rates, differential privacy, or algorithmic impact assessments). Reference frameworks if applicable (e.g., 'WHO Ethics Guidelines for AI in Health').

properties.label: Publication DOI
properties.description: Digital Object Identifier (DOI) for the primary research paper or preprint describing the model. Use full DOI URL (e.g., 'https://doi.org/10.1038/...').

properties.label: Adaptive Learning Mechanism
properties.description: Technical approach for model updates in response to new data or concept drift (e.g., online learning, continual learning, or periodic retraining). Specify trigger conditions if applicable.

properties.label: Visualization Tools
properties.description: Named tools or libraries used for generating actionable insights (e.g., Dash, Plotly, Kepler.gl, or custom WebGL-based dashboards).

values.value: quadratic equation

Modeling projections for cases and death.text: For the mathematical model, let three points P1 = (x1, y1), P2 = (x2, y2), and P3 = (x3, y3) such that y1 corresponds to number of cases or deaths of the date 30 days prior to the present day, x1 = 0, y2 corresponds to number of cases or deaths of the date 15 days prior to the present day, x2 = 15, y3 corresponds to number of cases or deaths of the present day, and x1 = 30. Based on the quadratic equation defined as f (x) = ax2 + bx + c...
Modeling projections for cases and death.relevance: Direct description of the core predictive model architecture (quadratic equation) used for projections, including its mathematical formulation and data points (30, 15, and 0 days prior).

Implementation.text: To perform the projection for estimating future cases and deaths, we developed a mathematical model focused on a quadratic equation based on data of present day and 30 previous days.
Implementation.relevance: Explicitly states the model type ('quadratic equation') and its purpose (projections for cases/deaths).

Results.text: Projected cases and deaths worldwide and by selected country. This information is calculated using the quadratic equation obtained through the developed mathematical model...
Results.relevance: Confirms the use of the quadratic equation model for generating projections, reinforcing its role as the core architecture.

values.value: JSON-to-PHP ETL pipeline with Apache server backend for WHO COVID-19 data (real-time API: https://dashboards-dev.sprinklr.com/data/9043/global-covid19-who-gis.json) combined with static CSV import (World Population Review 2020) into a unified PHP/MySQL persistence layer, using UML-designed object-oriented schema for semantic alignment of temporal case/death counts with population denominators

Implementation.text: The data source used in COVID-19 Dashboard is taken from the WHO (https://covid19.who.int/) and World Population Review (https://www.worldpopulationreview.com/). The first data set is accessed by COVID-19 Dashboard through the URL https://dashboards-dev.sprinklr.com/data/9043/global-covid19-who-gis.json. This information is in JSON format; then, the system includes the algorithms to decode this format before processing the information. The second data set is downloaded in CSV format and included in the persistence layer of the system. This project deploys different graphics to analyze the information from different perspectives... For the design of COVID-19 Dashboard, Unified Modeling Language (UML) was used allowing the description of the software based on the Object Oriented Paradigm.
Implementation.relevance: Explicitly describes (1) dual-source integration (JSON API + CSV), (2) ETL pipeline components (decoding, persistence layer), (3) semantic alignment via UML/OOP schema, and (4) temporal handling of case/death counts with population data

values.value: Temporal alignment via 30-day rolling window for quadratic projection model, with daily WHO updates triggering automatic recalculation of coefficients (a, b, c) in f(x) = ax² + bx + c using linear algebra solver for P1(x1=0, y1=t-30), P2(x2=15, y2=t-15), P3(x3=30, y3=t)

Modeling projections for cases and death.text: For the mathematical model, let three points P1 = (x1, y1), P2 = (x2, y2), and P3 = (x3, y3) such that y1 corresponds to number of cases or deaths of the date 30 days prior to the present day, x1 = 0, y2 corresponds to number of cases or deaths of the date 15 days prior to the present day, x2 = 15, y3 corresponds to number of cases or deaths of the present day, and x3 = 30... Calculated quadratic equations will be adjusted when new information is reported by the WHO.
Modeling projections for cases and death.relevance: Details the temporal integration strategy for handling daily updates: (1) 30-day rolling window, (2) fixed temporal anchors (x1=0, x2=15, x3=30), (3) automatic recalculation on new data, and (4) linear algebra-based alignment of time-series data

values.value: Country-level spatial resolution

Implementation.text: COVID-19 Dashboard presents full information about COVID-19 focusing on cases and deaths **worldwide and by country**. To perform the projection for estimating future cases and deaths, we developed a mathematical model focused on a quadratic equation based on data of present day and 30 previous days. With the quadratic equation, projected cases and deaths for the next days **up to 90 days** are calculated.
Implementation.relevance: Explicitly states spatial granularity (country-level) and temporal granularity (daily projections up to 90 days). The adaptive aspect is implied by the model stopping early if the quadratic equation reaches a maximum before 90 days (see 'Modeling projections' section).

Modeling projections for cases and death.text: COVID-19 Dashboard offers a projection for 90 days; nevertheless, for some countries, the quadratic equation could rise to a maximum point; in these cases, the algorithms will stop calculating and thus the **projected days will be lower than 90 days**.
Modeling projections for cases and death.relevance: Confirms adaptive temporal resolution (projection horizon adjusts dynamically based on model behavior).

Results.text: Projected cases and deaths **worldwide and by selected country**... presented using a line chart with two series. The first presents the **actual cases or deaths for the last 31 days**. The second presents the **projected cases or deaths up to 90 days after the last day reported**.
Results.relevance: Reinforces country-level spatial resolution and daily temporal alignment (31-day historical + up-to-90-day forecast).

values.value: Quadratic equation fit quality for 30-day rolling projections

Modeling projections for cases and death.text: Based on a, b, and c applied to the quadratic equation, the projected cases and deaths are calculated. [...] COVID-19 Dashboard offers a projection for 90 days; nevertheless, for some countries, the quadratic equation could rise to a maximum point; in these cases, the algorithms will stop calculating and thus the projected days will be lower than 90 days. [...] Figure 7 presents four charts with cases and death projections [...] This projection presents a exponential/logarithmic growth, which implies that COVID-19 in [country] will continue to impact/decrease.
Modeling projections for cases and death.relevance: Describes the core validation approach: visual comparison of quadratic projections (red lines) against actual WHO data (blue lines) in Figure 7, with growth pattern classification (exponential/logarithmic) serving as a qualitative metric. The 30-day rolling window and dynamic adjustment of projection horizon (≤90 days) are implicit validation constraints.

Results.text: Projected cases and deaths worldwide and by selected country. This information is calculated using the quadratic equation obtained through the developed mathematical model (as above). It is presented using a line chart with two series. The first presents the actual cases or deaths for the last 31 days. The second presents the projected cases or deaths up to 90 days after the last day reported.
Results.relevance: Explicitly states the dual-series line chart (actual vs. projected) as the primary validation visualization, with temporal alignment (31-day baseline → 90-day forecast) as the evaluation framework.

Discussion.text: COVID-19 Dashboard has an additional important contribution not presented in other projects. This is the mathematical model that projects future cases and deaths worldwide and by country. This mathematical model is based on linear algebra and calculates a quadratic equation based on the information reported in the last 31 days. Thus, the mathematical model is able to adjust the quadratic equation once new information is reported.
Discussion.relevance: Highlights the adaptive 31-day quadratic fit as the model's unique validation mechanism, with continuous adjustment serving as an implicit performance metric.

Modeling projections for cases and death.relevance: Describes the core computational approach (quadratic equation fitting using 31-day data) and projection horizon (up to 90 days), with dynamic adjustment for new data. The complexity is inherently O(1) per projection due to fixed 3-point interpolation, but requires O(n) for 90-day extrapolation where n=90.

Results.relevance: Confirms the 31-day input window and 90-day output horizon, implying a fixed computational pattern per country/global projection.

text_sections.Online dashboard and data analysis appro:
Hector Florez  Roles:  Conceptualization, Formal Analysis, Software, Writing – Original Draft Preparation   Sweta Singh  Roles:  Conceptualization, Formal Analysis, Validation, Writing – Review & Editing
This article is included in the Emerging Diseases and Outbreaks gateway.
This article is included in the Coronavirus (COVID-19) collection.
text_sections.Keywords: COVID-19, SARS-CoV-2, Data analysis, Mathematical model
text_sections.Introduction:
Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is caused by Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), which is a virus strain that causes respiratory illness. This virus was identified in December, 2019 and its first infection case was reported on December 30, 2019 in Wuhan city located in Hubei providence, China1. The World Health Organization (WHO) recognized the disease as a pandemic on March 11 20202. The WHO have reported the following numbers of cases and deaths worldwide: January 31, 9,847 cases and 213 deaths3; February 29, 85,961 cases and 2,941 deaths4; March 31, 754,933 cases and 36,522 deaths5; and April 30, 3,096,626 cases and 217,896 deaths6. These reports show an increment of cases in February of 872.97%, in March of 878.22%, and in April of 410.18%, as well as an increment of deaths in February of 1,387.26%, in March of 1,241.82%, and in April of 596.61%7. Based on these percentiles, we can observe an exponential growth of the disease.
Based on this previous data, it is important to analyze the evolution of the disease in order to make decisions that tackle the growth rate of cases and deaths. Therefore, in this work, we have designed and developed an online dashboard which presents two types of results: (1) actual information about the COVID-19 using different deployment strategies; and (2) based on the actual information, a projection in order to estimate the future behavior of the disease calculated worldwide and by country. To achieve this projection, we have designed a mathematical model based on previous data reported by the WHO.
text_sections.Implementation:
To analyze the current state of COVID-19, we have created an online information system called COVID-19 Dashboard, which is accessible from: https://covid19.itiud.org/. For the design of COVID-19 Dashboard, Unified Modeling Language (UML)8 was used allowing the description of the software based on the Object Oriented Paradigm9,10. It has been developed using: a) PHP 7.4.5 (https://www.php.net/) supported by Apache 2.4.43 (https://www.apache.org/); b) Bootstrap 4.4.1 (https://www.getbootstrap.com/) for responsive front-end; c) jQuery 3.3.1 (https://www.jquery.com/) as JavaScript library.
COVID-19 Dashboard presents full information about COVID-19 focusing on cases and deaths worldwide and by country. In addition, it includes a mathematical model in order to calculate projections for future cases and deaths. The data source used in COVID-19 Dashboard is taken from the WHO (https://covid19.who.int/) and World Population Review (https://www.worldpopulationreview.com/). The first data set is accessed by COVID-19 Dashboard through the URL https://dashboards-dev.sprinklr.com/data/9043/global-covid19-who-gis.json. This information is in JSON format; then, the system includes the algorithms to decode this format before processing the information. The second data set is downloaded in CSV format and included in the persistence layer of the system.This project deploys different graphics to analyze the information from different perspectives11. These graphics are generated based on the JavaScript library Chartkick 2.7.2 (https://www.chartkick.com/), which is supported by Google Charts (https://developers.google.com/chart).
To perform the projection for estimating future cases and deaths, we developed a mathematical model focused on a quadratic equation12 based on data of present day and 30 previous days. With the quadratic equation, projected cases and deaths for the next days up to 90 days are calculated. The quadratic equation obtained for each projection is deployed supported by the JavaScript library Mathjax (https://www.mathjax.org/).
Figure 1 presents the components of the system, where all mentioned libraries are connected to COVID-19 Dashboard. The conceptual models of COVID-19 Dashboard have been created using the modeling tool UML Designer 9.0.0 (http://www.umldesigner.org/). The selected Integrated Development Environment (IDE) was Eclipse-PHP 2020-03 (https://www.eclipse.org/) and the server used to host the project was Debian Linux Server 10.4 (https://www.debian.org/)13.
text_sections.Modeling projections for cases and death:
For the mathematical model, let three points P1 = (x1, y1), P2 = (x2, y2), and P3 = (x3, y3) such that y1 corresponds to number of cases or deaths of the date 30 days prior to the present day, x1 = 0, y2 corresponds to number of cases or deaths of the date 15 days prior to the present day, x2 = 15, y3 corresponds to number of cases or deaths of the present day, and x1 = 30. Based on the quadratic equation defined as f (x) = ax2 + bx + c, let the equation system presented in (1), (2), and (3).
y1=ax12+bx1+c(1)
y2=ax22+bx2+c(2)
y3=ax32+bx+c(3)
Since x1 = 0 from (1):
y1=c(4)
Subtracting (2) from (4):
y1−y2=−ax22−bx2(5)
Isolating the variable b from (5):
b=y1−y2+ax22−x2(6)
Subtracting (2) from (3):
y3−y2=a(x32−x22)+b(x3−x2)(7)
Replacing b in (7):
y3−y2=a(x32−x22)+y1−y2+ax22−x2(x3−x2)y3−y2=a(x32−x22)+(y1−y2)(x3−x2)−x2−ax2(x3−x2)y3−y2=a((x32−x22)−x2(x3−x2))−(y1−y2)(x3−x2)x2(8)
Isolating the variable a from (8):
a=y3−y2((x32−x22)−x2(x3−x2))+(y1−y2)(x3−x2)x2((x32−x22)−x2(x3−x2))(9)
Finally, isolating the variable c from (4):
c=y1(10)
Therefore, based on a, b, and c applied to the quadratic equation, the projected cases and deaths are calculated. In addition, calculated quadratic equations will be adjusted when new information is reported by the WHO. Furthermore, COVID-19 Dashboard offers a projection for 90 days; nevertheless, for some countries, the quadratic equation could rise to a maximum point; in these cases, the algorithms will stop calculating and thus the projected days will be lower than 90 days.
Consequently, COVID-19 Dashboard allows analyzing confirmed cases, deaths, and mortality rates as well as projecting cases and death deploying information in: a) geographic charts to understand the country distribution of the disease, b) bar charts to recognize the most impacted countries, c) column charts to present the evolution of the disease over time, and d) line charts to estimate the behavior of the disease.
text_sections.Operation: COVID-19 Dashboard is an online responsive system; therefore, it is accessible for users via a web browser through desktops, laptops, smart phones, and tablets. Its front-end can automatically adjust to any screen resolution in order to deploy the information in the best possible way.
text_sections.Results:
COVID-19 Dashboard is able to process the data provided by the WHO related to COVID-19 rates and World Population Review related to the current world population. This system deploys up-to-date information as follows: Cases and deaths by country. This information is presented in two ways: geographic charts and bar charts in order to recognize the most impacted countries.Cases and deaths by country per million people. This information is also presented by geographic and bar charts.Mortality rate by country. For this information, the mortality rate is calculated for each country and is presented by geographic and bar charts.Cases and deaths by date worldwide and by selected country. This information is calculated based on the daily information reported by each country. This is presented in two column charts. The first column chart presents the daily cases, while the second column chart presents the cumulative cases.Projected cases and deaths worldwide and by selected country. This information is calculated using the quadratic equation obtained through the developed mathematical model (as above). It is presented using a line chart with two series. The first presents the actual cases or deaths for the last 31 days. The second presents the projected cases or deaths up to 90 days after the last day reported.
Cases and deaths by country. This information is presented in two ways: geographic charts and bar charts in order to recognize the most impacted countries.
Cases and deaths by country per million people. This information is also presented by geographic and bar charts.
Mortality rate by country. For this information, the mortality rate is calculated for each country and is presented by geographic and bar charts.
Cases and deaths by date worldwide and by selected country. This information is calculated based on the daily information reported by each country. This is presented in two column charts. The first column chart presents the daily cases, while the second column chart presents the cumulative cases.
Projected cases and deaths worldwide and by selected country. This information is calculated using the quadratic equation obtained through the developed mathematical model (as above). It is presented using a line chart with two series. The first presents the actual cases or deaths for the last 31 days. The second presents the projected cases or deaths up to 90 days after the last day reported.
As mentioned above, the number of cases, deaths, and mortality rates are deployed using geographic charts. Figure 2 presents a geographic chart with the number of deaths by country, where red implies a large number of deaths and light blue implies a low number of deaths. On the date that this chart was obtained from COVID-19 Dashboard, the United States had the largest number of deaths worldwide followed by Spain, France, Italy and the United Kingdom. However, just using the color coding, it is not clear if Spain, France, Italy or the United Kingdom has the second highest number of deaths. Similarly, for the lower number of deaths seen in Belgium, Brazil, Germany, Canada, Turkey, Netherlands, Iran, and China, it is not clear which has the lowest number of deaths using the color coding.
text_sections.Figure 2. Geographic chart from COVID-19:
Red = high number of deaths; light blue = low number of deaths. Chart captured on May 29th 2020.
Consequently, it is necessary to sort the countries based on the actual number of deaths in addition to the color coding. Figure 3 presents a fragment of a bar chart with the number of deaths per country sorted by number of deaths. This chart shows that the United States has more than the double of deaths of Italy and the United Kingdom. In addition, Spain and France have almost the same number, but a little less than Italy and United Kingdom, followed by Brazil, while Belgium, Mexico, Germany, Iran, and Canada have similar number of deaths but much less than Spain and France. Finally, Netherlands, India, China, Turkey, Russia, and Sweden have less but a still important number of cases.
text_sections.Figure 3. Fragment of a bar chart from C:
Chart captured on May 29th 2020.
It is also important to assess information about COVID-19 based on the population by country. Figure 4 presents a geographic chart with the number of cases by countries per million people. Although United States has the largest number of cases, this chart presents that countries such as Spain, Ireland, and Belgium have more cases per million than United States, while Italy, Switzerland, United Kingdom, Portugal, and Sweden have also a large number of cases per million.
text_sections.Figure 4. Geographic chart from COVID-19:
Chart captured on May 29th 2020.
Additionally, the COVID-19 Dashboard shows the mortality rate per country, as shown in Figure 5. Although the United States has the largest number of deaths, it also has a very large number of cases. However, countries such as Italy, United Kingdom, Spain, and France have a higher mortality rate than the United States. Surprisingly, the country with the highest mortality rate by May 29th is Yemen (21.63%), showing the very serious public health issue for this country.
text_sections.Figure 5. Fragment of bar chart from COV:
Chart captured on May 29th 2020.
Nevertheless, it is important to take into account that this country has reported little information. Countries such as France, Belgium, Italy, United Kingdom, and Spain are in the top 10 of this list, which implies that they have a high mortality risk, perhaps due to the high number of active cases.
Further information to be analyzed is cases and deaths per date. Figure 6 presents two charts. Figure 6(a) shows the number of confirmed cases per day in Colombia, while (b) shows cumulative cases per day in Colombia. Figure 6(a) shows that from April 1 2020, the number of cases was stable with peaks in the last few days, while Figure 6(b) shows stable behavior with a small increment of cumulative cases from April. It implies that COVID-19 keeps impacting health in Colombia and cases will increase until its behavior changes.
text_sections.Figure 6. Bar chart from COVID-19 Dashbo:
Chart captured on May 29th 2020.
Based these previous results, it is really important to know the trend of cases and deaths worldwide and by country. Thus, COVID-19 Dashboard includes a very important contribution, i.e. the mathematical model already described, which allows projection for future cases and deaths worldwide and by country. Figure 7 presents four charts with cases and death projections.
text_sections.Figure 7. Cases and death projections fr:
Chart captured on May 29th 2020.
Figure 7(a) presents projected cases in Colombia. Blue corresponds to the actual cases reported by the WHO, while red corresponds to the projected cases and yellow the increment of cases per day. This projection performed on May 29th 2020 produced the quadratic equation:
f(x)=11.46x2+273.10x+5,597.00(11)
This projection presents a exponential growth, which implies that COVID-19 in Colombia will continue to impact public health.
Figure 7(b) presents projected cases in Russia. This projection performed on May 29th 2020 produced the quadratic equation:
f(x)=−38.82x2+10,772.00x+99,399.00(12)
This projection presents a logarithmic growth, which implies that deaths for COVID-19 in Russia are decreasing considerably and might stop in 61 days.
Figure 7(c) presents projected deaths in India. This projection performed on May 29th 2020 produced the quadratic equation:
f(x)=1.37x2+82.30x+1,007.00(13)
This projection presents a exponential growth, which implies that deaths for COVID-19 in India are still increasing.
Figure 7(d) presents projected deaths worldwide. This projection performed on May 29th 2020 produced the quadratic equation:
f(x)=−41.22x2+6,224.23x+208,111.00(14)
This projection presents a logarithmic growth, which implies that deaths for COVID-19 worldwide might start decreasing in the first week of July.
Quadratic equations are presented with coefficients with two decimals; however, all calculations are done with the real calculated values for their coefficients.
text_sections.Discussion:
COVID-19 has required analysis of data regarding cases and deaths reported worldwide. Some projects developed by important organizations such as COVID-19 Dashboard by the Center for Systems Science and Engineering (CSSE) at Johns Hopkins University (JHU) (https://coronavirus.jhu.edu/map.html) and Coronavirus Disease (COVID-19) Dashboard by the World Health Organization (https://covid19.who.int/) have provided very interesting visualizations for reporting the current state of the COVID-19. Nevertheless, these projects lack important information and analysis. With this in mind, the COVID-19 Dashboard presented here has been designed and developed in order to offer additional valuable information. This project uses the data reported by the WHO; therefore, it is able to deploy the same information as the WHO COVID-Dashboard. However, COVID-19 Dashboard is able to deploy more information such as cases and deaths per million people worldwide and mortality rate worldwide, which is also very important to assess the impact of the disease from different perspectives.
Moreover, COVID-19 Dashboard has an additional important contribution not presented in other projects. This is the mathematical model that projects future cases and deaths worldwide and by country. This mathematical model is based on linear algebra and calculates a quadratic equation based on the information reported in the last 31 days. Thus, the mathematical model is able to adjust the quadratic equation once new information is reported. With this model, COVID-19 Dashboard is able to estimate the number of new cases and deaths up to 90 days.
text_sections.Conclusions: COVID-19 Dashboard allows understanding COVID-19 behavior and evolution from different perspectives. Based on those perspectives, it is possible to assess not only the actual number of cases and deaths worldwide and by country, but also the most impacted countries by observing the number of cases and deaths per million people and mortality rate. COVID-19 Dashboard offers a projection of future cases and deaths, which is an important tool to estimate the disease’s evolution. Based on these projections, health organizations around the world might take action in order to minimize the impact, as well as estimate the date when the COVID-19 might stop impacting various countries.

values.value: quadratic equation

Modeling projections for cases and death.text: For the mathematical model, let three points P1 = (x1, y1), P2 = (x2, y2), and P3 = (x3, y3) such that y1 corresponds to number of cases or deaths of the date 30 days prior to the present day, x1 = 0, y2 corresponds to number of cases or deaths of the date 15 days prior to the present day, x2 = 15, y3 corresponds to number of cases or deaths of the present day, and x1 = 30. Based on the quadratic equation defined as f (x) = ax2 + bx + c...
Modeling projections for cases and death.relevance: Direct description of the core predictive model architecture (quadratic equation) used for projections, including its mathematical formulation and data points (30, 15, and 0 days prior).

Implementation.text: To perform the projection for estimating future cases and deaths, we developed a mathematical model focused on a quadratic equation based on data of present day and 30 previous days.
Implementation.relevance: Explicitly states the model type ('quadratic equation') and its purpose (projections for cases/deaths).

Results.text: Projected cases and deaths worldwide and by selected country. This information is calculated using the quadratic equation obtained through the developed mathematical model...
Results.relevance: Confirms the use of the quadratic equation model for generating projections, reinforcing its role as the core architecture.

values.value: JSON-to-PHP ETL pipeline with Apache server backend for WHO COVID-19 data (real-time API: https://dashboards-dev.sprinklr.com/data/9043/global-covid19-who-gis.json) combined with static CSV import (World Population Review 2020) into a unified PHP/MySQL persistence layer, using UML-designed object-oriented schema for semantic alignment of temporal case/death counts with population denominators

Implementation.text: The data source used in COVID-19 Dashboard is taken from the WHO (https://covid19.who.int/) and World Population Review (https://www.worldpopulationreview.com/). The first data set is accessed by COVID-19 Dashboard through the URL https://dashboards-dev.sprinklr.com/data/9043/global-covid19-who-gis.json. This information is in JSON format; then, the system includes the algorithms to decode this format before processing the information. The second data set is downloaded in CSV format and included in the persistence layer of the system. This project deploys different graphics to analyze the information from different perspectives... For the design of COVID-19 Dashboard, Unified Modeling Language (UML) was used allowing the description of the software based on the Object Oriented Paradigm.
Implementation.relevance: Explicitly describes (1) dual-source integration (JSON API + CSV), (2) ETL pipeline components (decoding, persistence layer), (3) semantic alignment via UML/OOP schema, and (4) temporal handling of case/death counts with population data

values.value: Temporal alignment via 30-day rolling window for quadratic projection model, with daily WHO updates triggering automatic recalculation of coefficients (a, b, c) in f(x) = ax² + bx + c using linear algebra solver for P1(x1=0, y1=t-30), P2(x2=15, y2=t-15), P3(x3=30, y3=t)

Modeling projections for cases and death.text: For the mathematical model, let three points P1 = (x1, y1), P2 = (x2, y2), and P3 = (x3, y3) such that y1 corresponds to number of cases or deaths of the date 30 days prior to the present day, x1 = 0, y2 corresponds to number of cases or deaths of the date 15 days prior to the present day, x2 = 15, y3 corresponds to number of cases or deaths of the present day, and x3 = 30... Calculated quadratic equations will be adjusted when new information is reported by the WHO.
Modeling projections for cases and death.relevance: Details the temporal integration strategy for handling daily updates: (1) 30-day rolling window, (2) fixed temporal anchors (x1=0, x2=15, x3=30), (3) automatic recalculation on new data, and (4) linear algebra-based alignment of time-series data

values.value: Country-level spatial resolution

Implementation.text: COVID-19 Dashboard presents full information about COVID-19 focusing on cases and deaths **worldwide and by country**. To perform the projection for estimating future cases and deaths, we developed a mathematical model focused on a quadratic equation based on data of present day and 30 previous days. With the quadratic equation, projected cases and deaths for the next days **up to 90 days** are calculated.
Implementation.relevance: Explicitly states spatial granularity (country-level) and temporal granularity (daily projections up to 90 days). The adaptive aspect is implied by the model stopping early if the quadratic equation reaches a maximum before 90 days (see 'Modeling projections' section).

Modeling projections for cases and death.text: COVID-19 Dashboard offers a projection for 90 days; nevertheless, for some countries, the quadratic equation could rise to a maximum point; in these cases, the algorithms will stop calculating and thus the **projected days will be lower than 90 days**.
Modeling projections for cases and death.relevance: Confirms adaptive temporal resolution (projection horizon adjusts dynamically based on model behavior).

Results.text: Projected cases and deaths **worldwide and by selected country**... presented using a line chart with two series. The first presents the **actual cases or deaths for the last 31 days**. The second presents the **projected cases or deaths up to 90 days after the last day reported**.
Results.relevance: Reinforces country-level spatial resolution and daily temporal alignment (31-day historical + up-to-90-day forecast).

values.value: Quadratic equation fit quality for 30-day rolling projections

Modeling projections for cases and death.text: Based on a, b, and c applied to the quadratic equation, the projected cases and deaths are calculated. [...] COVID-19 Dashboard offers a projection for 90 days; nevertheless, for some countries, the quadratic equation could rise to a maximum point; in these cases, the algorithms will stop calculating and thus the projected days will be lower than 90 days. [...] Figure 7 presents four charts with cases and death projections [...] This projection presents a exponential/logarithmic growth, which implies that COVID-19 in [country] will continue to impact/decrease.
Modeling projections for cases and death.relevance: Describes the core validation approach: visual comparison of quadratic projections (red lines) against actual WHO data (blue lines) in Figure 7, with growth pattern classification (exponential/logarithmic) serving as a qualitative metric. The 30-day rolling window and dynamic adjustment of projection horizon (≤90 days) are implicit validation constraints.

Results.text: Projected cases and deaths worldwide and by selected country. This information is calculated using the quadratic equation obtained through the developed mathematical model (as above). It is presented using a line chart with two series. The first presents the actual cases or deaths for the last 31 days. The second presents the projected cases or deaths up to 90 days after the last day reported.
Results.relevance: Explicitly states the dual-series line chart (actual vs. projected) as the primary validation visualization, with temporal alignment (31-day baseline → 90-day forecast) as the evaluation framework.

Discussion.text: COVID-19 Dashboard has an additional important contribution not presented in other projects. This is the mathematical model that projects future cases and deaths worldwide and by country. This mathematical model is based on linear algebra and calculates a quadratic equation based on the information reported in the last 31 days. Thus, the mathematical model is able to adjust the quadratic equation once new information is reported.
Discussion.relevance: Highlights the adaptive 31-day quadratic fit as the model's unique validation mechanism, with continuous adjustment serving as an implicit performance metric.

values.value: Quadratic equation calculations based on 31-day historical data for 90-day projections

Modeling projections for cases and death.text: For the mathematical model, let three points P1 = (x1, y1), P2 = (x2, y2), and P3 = (x3, y3) such that y1 corresponds to number of cases or deaths of the date 30 days prior to the present day... Based on a, b, and c applied to the quadratic equation, the projected cases and deaths are calculated. Furthermore, COVID-19 Dashboard offers a projection for 90 days; nevertheless, for some countries, the quadratic equation could rise to a maximum point; in these cases, the algorithms will stop calculating and thus the projected days will be lower than 90 days.
Modeling projections for cases and death.relevance: Describes the core computational approach (quadratic equation fitting using 31-day data) and projection horizon (up to 90 days), with dynamic adjustment for new data. The complexity is inherently O(1) per projection due to fixed 3-point interpolation, but requires O(n) for 90-day extrapolation where n=90.

Results.text: Projected cases and deaths worldwide and by selected country. This information is calculated using the quadratic equation obtained through the developed mathematical model (as above). It is presented using a line chart with two series. The first presents the actual cases or deaths for the last 31 days. The second presents the projected cases or deaths up to 90 days after the last day reported.
Results.relevance: Confirms the 31-day input window and 90-day output horizon, implying a fixed computational pattern per country/global projection.

Modeling projections for cases and death.text: For the mathematical model, let three points P1 = (x1, y1), P2 = (x2, y2), and P3 = (x3, y3) such that y1 corresponds to number of cases or deaths of the date 30 days prior to the present day, x1 = 0, y2 corresponds to number of cases or deaths of the date 15 days prior to the present day, x2 = 15, y3 corresponds to number of cases or deaths of the present day, and x3 = 30. Based on the quadratic equation defined as f(x) = ax² + bx + c, let the equation system presented in (1), (2), and (3).
Modeling projections for cases and death.relevance: Describes the explicit use of a quadratic equation (f(x) = ax² + bx + c) as the calibration method for fitting model parameters to historical COVID-19 case/death data points (P1, P2, P3). The method involves solving a system of equations derived from 30-day, 15-day, and present-day data to determine coefficients a, b, and c.

Discussion.text: This mathematical model is based on linear algebra and calculates a quadratic equation based on the information reported in the last 31 days.
Discussion.relevance: Confirms the calibration method relies on linear algebra to fit a quadratic equation to the most recent 31 days of data, reinforcing the technical approach described in the *Modeling projections* section.

Introduction.text: This virus was identified in December, 2019 and its first infection case was reported on December 30, 2019 in Wuhan city... The WHO have reported the following numbers of cases and deaths worldwide: January 31, 9,847 cases and 213 deaths; February 29, 85,961 cases and 2,941 deaths; March 31, 754,933 cases and 36,522 deaths; and April 30, 3,096,626 cases and 217,896 deaths... Chart captured on May 29th 2020.
Introduction.relevance: Explicit reference to the earliest reported case (2019-12-30) as the start of data collection, with projections and visualizations generated up to May 29, 2020 (end date). The WHO-reported monthly snapshots (Jan–Apr 2020) and the May 29 capture date in figures confirm the active period of data used for both historical analysis and model training.

Results.text: Chart captured on May 29th 2020.
Results.relevance: Final date stamp for the most recent data used in the dashboard's visualizations and projections, marking the end of the primary collection period.

Introduction.text: No mention of ethical AI, bias mitigation, or fairness considerations in the design or analysis of the COVID-19 Dashboard or mathematical model.
Introduction.relevance: Absence of evidence for ethical AI measures in the system's conceptualization or implementation.

Implementation.text: The mathematical model and dashboard design focus solely on data processing and projection without addressing demographic stratification, fairness, or ethical risk assessments. Data sources (WHO and World Population Review) are used as-is without validation for representativeness or bias.
Implementation.relevance: Technical implementation lacks any explicit mechanisms for bias detection, differential privacy, or alignment with ethical frameworks (e.g., WHO Ethics Guidelines for AI in Health).

Modeling projections for cases and death.text: The quadratic equation for projections relies on aggregated case/death counts without disaggregation by demographic groups (e.g., age, gender, socioeconomic status) or error analysis across subgroups.

metadata.template_name: Technical Framework for Predictive Modeling of Dynamic Disease Spread and Impact Projection

metadata.title: Online dashboard and data analysis approach for assessing COVID-19 case and death data
metadata.abstract: The 2019-2020 global pandemic has been caused by a disease called coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19). This disease has been caused by the Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome coronavirus-2 (SARS-CoV-2). By April 30 2020, the World Health Organization reported 3,096,626 cases and 217,896 deaths, which implies an exponential growth for infection and deaths worldwide. Currently, there are various computer-based approaches that present COVID-19 data through different types of charts, which is very useful to recognise its behavior and trends. Nevertheless, such approaches do not allow for observation of any projection regarding confirmed cases and deaths, which would be useful to understand the trends of COVID-19. In this work, we have designed and developed an online dashboard that presents actual information about COVID-19. Furthermore, based on this information, we have designed a mathematical model in order to make projections about the evolution of cases and deaths worldwide and by country.

selectedProblem.title: Predictive Modeling for Dynamic Disease Spread and Impact Projection

llm_problem.title: Predictive Modeling for Dynamic Disease Spread and Impact Projection
llm_problem.problem: The challenge of developing robust, real-time predictive models to project the spread and impact of infectious diseases such as COVID-19 (e.g., case counts, fatalities) at global and regional scales. This requires integrating heterogeneous data sources, accounting for uncertainty, and enabling actionable insights for public health decision-making beyond static descriptive analytics.
llm_problem.impact: Enhances pandemic preparedness and response by enabling data-driven forecasting of disease trajectories, resource allocation, and policy interventions. Applications extend to other infectious diseases (e.g., influenza, dengue) and emerging health threats, as well as cross-domain scenarios like environmental risk modeling or supply chain disruption prediction.
llm_problem.motivation: Static visualizations of disease data (e.g., dashboards) provide limited foresight into future trends, whereas accurate projections empower stakeholders—from policymakers to healthcare providers—to anticipate critical inflection points, mitigate risks, and optimize interventions. Addressing this gap is vital for reducing morbidity, mortality, and socioeconomic disruption during outbreaks.
llm_problem.explanation: The abstract explicitly contrasts descriptive analytics (existing dashboards) with the unmet need for *projections*, framing a clear, domain-agnostic research challenge. The problem is well-scoped (dynamic modeling vs. static reporting), broadly applicable (infectious diseases, other dynamic systems), and grounded in a tangible public health priority. Minor deduction for potential overlap with related fields (e.g., time-series forecasting), but the focus on *actionable projections* for decision-making strengthens clarity.

values.value: Country-level spatial resolution

Implementation.text: COVID-19 Dashboard presents full information about COVID-19 focusing on cases and deaths **worldwide and by country**. To perform the projection for estimating future cases and deaths, we developed a mathematical model focused on a quadratic equation based on data of present day and 30 previous days. With the quadratic equation, projected cases and deaths for the next days **up to 90 days** are calculated.
Implementation.relevance: Explicitly states spatial granularity (country-level) and temporal granularity (daily projections up to 90 days). The adaptive aspect is implied by the model stopping early if the quadratic equation reaches a maximum before 90 days (see 'Modeling projections' section).

Modeling projections for cases and death.text: COVID-19 Dashboard offers a projection for 90 days; nevertheless, for some countries, the quadratic equation could rise to a maximum point; in these cases, the algorithms will stop calculating and thus the **projected days will be lower than 90 days**.
Modeling projections for cases and death.relevance: Confirms adaptive temporal resolution (projection horizon adjusts dynamically based on model behavior).

Results.text: Projected cases and deaths **worldwide and by selected country**... presented using a line chart with two series. The first presents the **actual cases or deaths for the last 31 days**. The second presents the **projected cases or deaths up to 90 days after the last day reported**.
Results.relevance: Reinforces country-level spatial resolution and daily temporal alignment (31-day historical + up-to-90-day forecast).

Introduction.text: No mention of ethical AI, bias mitigation, or fairness considerations in the design or analysis of the COVID-19 Dashboard or mathematical model.
Introduction.relevance: Absence of evidence for ethical AI measures in the system's conceptualization or implementation.

Implementation.text: The mathematical model and dashboard design focus solely on data processing and projection without addressing demographic stratification, fairness, or ethical risk assessments. Data sources (WHO and World Population Review) are used as-is without validation for representativeness or bias.
Implementation.relevance: Technical implementation lacks any explicit mechanisms for bias detection, differential privacy, or alignment with ethical frameworks (e.g., WHO Ethics Guidelines for AI in Health).

Modeling projections for cases and death.text: The quadratic equation for projections relies on aggregated case/death counts without disaggregation by demographic groups (e.g., age, gender, socioeconomic status) or error analysis across subgroups.
Modeling projections for cases and death.relevance: No evidence of algorithmic impact assessments or fairness-aware modeling techniques.

Discussion.text: Comparison with other dashboards (e.g., JHU, WHO) highlights missing features but does not address ethical limitations or bias in the proposed tool.
Discussion.relevance: Omission of ethical considerations as a potential gap in the tool's contributions.

values.value: Quadratic equation model recalculated daily using 31-day rolling window of WHO-reported COVID-19 case/death data, with automatic coefficient adjustment upon new data availability

Modeling projections for cases and death.text: calculated quadratic equations will be adjusted when new information is reported by the WHO. Furthermore, COVID-19 Dashboard offers a projection for 90 days; nevertheless, for some countries, the quadratic equation could rise to a maximum point; in these cases, the algorithms will stop calculating and thus the projected days will be lower than 90 days.
Modeling projections for cases and death.relevance: Explicitly describes the adaptive mechanism where the quadratic model coefficients (a, b, c) are recalculated when new WHO data becomes available, using a 31-day rolling window (P1=30 days prior, P2=15 days prior, P3=current day) as detailed in equations (1)-(10).

Discussion.text: This mathematical model is based on linear algebra and calculates a quadratic equation based on the information reported in the last 31 days. Thus, the mathematical model is able to adjust the quadratic equation once new information is reported.
Discussion.relevance: Confirms the adaptive mechanism is triggered by new WHO data reports and operates on a fixed 31-day window.
